questions.text: Artery supplying near marked structure is (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anterior interventricular artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The anterior interventricular artery (LAD) supplies the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum and is critical for heart function, making it a key vessel in coronary circulation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with visual acuity of 6/18, which improves upon performing the pinhole test. During the examination, the presence of fibrosis in the lens nucleus is noted, and his near vision displays improvement. Based on these findings, what is the refractive error he is presenting with? ( FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Index myopia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Index myopia is characterized by an increase in the refractive index of the lens nucleus, often associated with nuclear sclerosis in cataracts, and can result in the "second sight phenomenon," where near vision temporarily improves

questions.text: Which value is derived in ABG?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bicarbonate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis, pH, pO2 (partial pressure of oxygen), and pCO2 (partial pressure of carbon dioxide) are measured directly by the ABG machine.
  • • ABG machine.
  • • Bicarbonate (HCO3-) is not directly measured but is derived using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation . The equation relates the pH, pCO2, and bicarbonate concentration, enabling the calculation of bicarbonate from the directly measured values of pH and pCO2.
  • • Henderson-Hasselbalch equation
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. pH : This is directly measured in ABG analysis using an electrode sensitive to hydrogen ions.
  • • Option A. pH
  • • Option B. pO2 : This is directly measured in ABG analysis using an oxygen-sensitive electrode.
  • • Option B. pO2
  • • Option C. pCO2 : This is directly measured in ABG analysis using a carbon dioxide-sensitive electrode.
  • • Option C. pCO2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In arterial blood gas analysis, bicarbonate (HCO3-) is the value that is derived, not directly measured, using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation.

questions.text: If a young female child is raped, the hymen is usually: (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Hymen does not rupture because opening is too small to allow penis to enter

options.label: B
options.text: The hymen does not rupture because Hymen is situated deep inside

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Both a and b

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of rape involving a young female, the hymen is usually not ruptured because the vaginal opening is very small, making penetration difficult, and the hymen is situated deeply. Additionally, children may not show signs of general violence due to their inability to resist, though severe injuries can occur in cases of great violence.

questions.text: Which of the following is true? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Creatinine clearance is lesser than Inulin clearance

options.label: B
options.text: Creatinine clearance is equal to Inulin clearance

options.label: C
options.text: Creatinine clearance is greater than Inulin clearance

questions.correct_answer: C. Creatinine clearance is greater than Inulin clearance
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Creatinine clearance is greater than Inulin clearance

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Creatinine clearance slightly overestimates GFR compared to inulin clearance. This is because, in addition to being filtered at the glomerulus, a small amount of creatinine is secreted by the renal tubules, resulting in a higher clearance value.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Creatinine Clearance is Lesser than Inulin Clearance: Creatinine clearance is often slightly higher than inulin clearance. While inulin is exclusively filtered at the glomerulus and not reabsorbed or secreted, creatinine, although primarily filtered, is also slightly secreted by the renal tubules. This secretion leads to a slightly higher clearance rate compared to inulin.
  • • Option A. Creatinine Clearance is Lesser than Inulin Clearance:
  • • Option B. Creatinine Clearance is Equal to Inulin Clearance: Although creatinine clearance is frequently used as a practical estimate of the glomerular filtration rate (GFR), it is not exactly equal to inulin clearance. Inulin clearance is a more accurate measure of GFR as it is neither reabsorbed nor secreted, whereas creatinine is slightly secreted.
  • • Option B. Creatinine Clearance is Equal to Inulin Clearance:
  • • Option D. None of the Above: The correct statement is that creatinine clearance is greater than inulin clearance, as explained above.
  • • Option D. None of the Above:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Creatinine and inulin are both substances that are used to measure kidney function. Creatinine is a waste product of muscle metabolism, while inulin is a plant-derived polysaccharide that is not normally produced by the human body.
  • ➤ Creatinine clearance is a measure of the rate at which creatinine is cleared from the blood by the kidneys, while inulin clearance is a measure of the rate at which inulin is cleared from the blood by the kidneys. In theory, the clearance rates of these two substances should be equal, as they are both freely filtered by the glomerulus (the filtering unit of the kidney) and are not reabsorbed or secreted by the tubules but in practice, creatinine clearance is generally slightly higher due to the tubular secretion of creatinine and the possibility of incomplete urine collection during the clearance test.
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 574
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 574

questions.text: Complex 4 inhibitor is? ( NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cyanide

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cyanide is a potent inhibitor of Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) in the electron transport chain (ETC). Complex IV is crucial for the final step of the electron transport chain, where it facilitates the transfer of electrons to oxygen, the final electron acceptor, to form water. By inhibiting Complex IV, cyanide prevents the reduction of oxygen, halting ATP production and leading to cellular hypoxia and energy failure.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Carbon Dioxide: Carbon dioxide is not an inhibitor of any of the electron transport chain complexes. It is a byproduct of cellular respiration and does not interfere with the function of the ETC complexes.
  • • Option B. Carbon Dioxide:
  • • Option C. Oligomycin: Oligomycin is an inhibitor of ATP synthase (Complex V) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the F0 subunit of ATP synthase, blocking the proton channel and preventing proton translocation across the inner mitochondrial membrane. This inhibition halts ATP synthesis from ADP and inorganic phosphate.
  • • Option C. Oligomycin:
  • • Option D. Antimycin: Antimycin is an inhibitor of Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the Qi site of cytochrome c reductase, blocking the transfer of electrons from ubiquinol to cytochrome c, disrupting the proton gradient and halting ATP synthesis.
  • • Option D. Antimycin:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inhibitor of ETC complexes
  • ➤ Inhibitor of ETC complexes

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 123

questions.text: A patient presents to you with an irregularly irregular pulse of 120/minute and a pulse deficit of 20. Which of the following would be the JVP finding? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In atrial fibrillation, the jugular venous pulse (JVP) typically shows an absent a wave due to the lack of coordinated atrial contraction.

questions.text: A woman with an obstetric score of G2P1 comes to the clinic at 14 weeks of gestation for her antenatal checkup. A uterine artery doppler was suggested by the doctor. What would it detect? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Early-onset preeclampsia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Early-onset preeclampsia: Uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks of gestation can detect markers predictive of early-onset preeclampsia. Raised pulsatility index (PI) in the uterine artery and notching of the uterine artery waveform are indicative markers. Biochemical markers for early-onset preeclampsia include decreased levels of PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, and PlGF, and increased levels of sFlt-1, sEng, and cell-free DNA. Predictors of Preeclampsia: History and Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP): A patient's medical history and MAP are initial predictors. Biophysical Markers: Uterine artery Doppler: Raised PI and notching of the waveform are early indicators. Biochemical Markers: Decreased: PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, PlGF. Increased: sFlt-1, sEng, cell-free DNA. Anti-angiogenic Factors: sFlt-1 and sEng are important markers indicating anti-angiogenic activity, which is associated with preeclampsia.
  • • Early-onset preeclampsia: Uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks of gestation can detect markers predictive of early-onset preeclampsia. Raised pulsatility index (PI) in the uterine artery and notching of the uterine artery waveform are indicative markers. Biochemical markers for early-onset preeclampsia include decreased levels of PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, and PlGF, and increased levels of sFlt-1, sEng, and cell-free DNA.
  • • Early-onset preeclampsia:
  • • Uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks of gestation can detect markers predictive of early-onset preeclampsia. Raised pulsatility index (PI) in the uterine artery and notching of the uterine artery waveform are indicative markers. Biochemical markers for early-onset preeclampsia include decreased levels of PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, and PlGF, and increased levels of sFlt-1, sEng, and cell-free DNA.
  • • Uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks of gestation can detect markers predictive of early-onset preeclampsia.
  • • Raised pulsatility index (PI) in the uterine artery and notching of the uterine artery waveform are indicative markers.
  • • Biochemical markers for early-onset preeclampsia include decreased levels of PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, and PlGF, and increased levels of sFlt-1, sEng, and cell-free DNA.
  • • Predictors of Preeclampsia: History and Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP): A patient's medical history and MAP are initial predictors. Biophysical Markers: Uterine artery Doppler: Raised PI and notching of the waveform are early indicators. Biochemical Markers: Decreased: PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, PlGF. Increased: sFlt-1, sEng, cell-free DNA. Anti-angiogenic Factors: sFlt-1 and sEng are important markers indicating anti-angiogenic activity, which is associated with preeclampsia.
  • • Predictors of Preeclampsia:
  • • History and Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP): A patient's medical history and MAP are initial predictors. Biophysical Markers: Uterine artery Doppler: Raised PI and notching of the waveform are early indicators. Biochemical Markers: Decreased: PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, PlGF. Increased: sFlt-1, sEng, cell-free DNA. Anti-angiogenic Factors: sFlt-1 and sEng are important markers indicating anti-angiogenic activity, which is associated with preeclampsia.
  • • History and Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP): A patient's medical history and MAP are initial predictors.
  • • History and Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP):
  • • A patient's medical history and MAP are initial predictors.
  • • A patient's medical history and MAP are initial predictors.
  • • Biophysical Markers: Uterine artery Doppler: Raised PI and notching of the waveform are early indicators.
  • • Biophysical Markers:
  • • Uterine artery Doppler: Raised PI and notching of the waveform are early indicators.
  • • Uterine artery Doppler: Raised PI and notching of the waveform are early indicators.
  • • Biochemical Markers: Decreased: PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, PlGF. Increased: sFlt-1, sEng, cell-free DNA.
  • • Biochemical Markers:
  • • Decreased: PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, PlGF. Increased: sFlt-1, sEng, cell-free DNA.
  • • Decreased: PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, PlGF.
  • • Increased: sFlt-1, sEng, cell-free DNA.
  • • Anti-angiogenic Factors: sFlt-1 and sEng are important markers indicating anti-angiogenic activity, which is associated with preeclampsia.
  • • Anti-angiogenic Factors:
  • • sFlt-1 and sEng are important markers indicating anti-angiogenic activity, which is associated with preeclampsia.
  • • sFlt-1 and sEng are important markers indicating anti-angiogenic activity, which is associated with preeclampsia.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Late-onset preeclampsia: Uterine artery Doppler is more predictive of early-onset rather than late-onset preeclampsia.
  • • Option B. Late-onset preeclampsia:
  • • Option C. Fetal growth restriction: While fetal growth restriction can be associated with preeclampsia, the uterine artery Doppler specifically predicts early-onset preeclampsia rather than fetal growth restriction alone.
  • • Option C. Fetal growth restriction:
  • • Option D. Placenta accreta: Uterine artery Doppler is not used to detect placenta accreta. Placenta accreta is typically diagnosed through ultrasound or MRI.
  • • Option D. Placenta accreta:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks gestation can predict early-onset preeclampsia by identifying raised pulsatility index (PI) and notching of the uterine artery waveform.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1818, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1818, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: In a 10-year-old school child, which of the following vaccines is given as a part of the school immunization program? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) TT/Td vaccine

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus is being evaluated for medications to manage their condition and prevent renal complications. Which of the following drugs will not delay progression of renal disease? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hydrochlorothiazide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hydrochlorothiazide does not delay the progression of renal disease in patients with type 2 diabetes. In contrast, SGLT2 inhibitors, finerenone, and angiotensin receptor blockers are all known to provide renal protection and slow the progression of diabetic kidney disease.

questions.text: A patient comes to the ER with a headache, describing it as the worst headache of his life. Initial NCCT shows SAH. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CT Angiography

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The description of the "worst headache of his life" is highly suggestive of a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). When an initial non-contrast CT (NCCT) confirms SAH, the next step is to identify the source of bleeding, which is most commonly an aneurysm.
  • • CT Angiography is the preferred next step to localize the aneurysm and plan further management.
  • • CT Angiography
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Lumbar puncture: Indicated if the initial CT scan is negative and there is still suspicion of SAH, to check for xanthochromia.
  • • Option B. Lumbar puncture:
  • • Option C. MRI brain: Not the initial choice for acute SAH diagnosis or aneurysm localization.
  • • Option C. MRI brain:
  • • Option D. V-P shunt: Used for hydrocephalus management, not for immediate SAH diagnosis and management.
  • • Option D. V-P shunt:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with confirmed subarachnoid hemorrhage on CT, the next step is CT Angiography to identify and localize the source of bleeding.

questions.text: A newborn is delivered with the defect seen in the image below. Identify the condition? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Omphalocele

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Omphalocele is a congenital abdominal wall defect where abdominal organs protrude into the base of the umbilical cord and are covered by a sac composed of peritoneum and amniotic membranes.

questions.text: IL-1 is activated by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Caspase – 1

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the detection of monkeypox? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) PCR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most effective and standard method for the detection of monkeypox is PCR, which detects the DNA of the orthopoxvirus in clinical specimens.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with history of acute MI complains of acute, severe, and diffuse abdominal pain accompanied by multiple episodes of vomiting. Upon examination, his pulse rate is 110bpm with an irregular rhythm, while his blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg. The abdomen looks soft, not swollen, and there are no bowel sounds. What potential diagnosis could be considered for this patient based on these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The given clinical scenario suggests acute mesenteric ischemia as a possible diagnosis. The most common cause of acute mesenteric ischemia is an embolus. The risk factors for acute mesenteric ischemia/embolus in the given clinical scenario are the presence of an irregularly irregular pulse suggestive of atrial fibrillation and a previous history of ischemic heart disease/myocardial infarction.
  • ➤ The sudden onset of severe abdominal pain in a patient with atrial fibrillation or atherosclerosis is the most important clue to an early diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia. The pain is typically in the central abdomen and out of proportion to the physical findings. Associated features may include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal distension, peritonitis, and passage of bloody stools.
  • ➤ Angiography is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia, and management involves laparotomy. The goal of operative exploration is to reset the compromised bowel and restore blood supply via embolectomy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male having pain and deformity of the tibia as shown in X-ray. He had history of trauma 2 years back. What is the most probable diagnosis?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chronic osteomyelitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The radiological image shown in the question and the clinical symptoms described are suggestive of chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old post-menopausal female came with persistent back ache, not responding to conservative treatment. She has a history of heavy weight lifting 4 months back with progressively increasing pain that worsens on walking and starts radiating down her legs within 100m range of walking, she however feels no pain on climbing up the stairs. Most probable diagnosis is? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Lumbar canal stenosis

questions.text: Which of the following samples is considered the best for detecting lead poisoning? (FMGE 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Blood

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Lead poisoning primarily affects the synthesis of heme by inhibiting three crucial enzymes: Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase (ALAD), Coproporphyrinogen oxidase, and Ferrochelatase . This inhibition leads to the accumulation of their immediate precursors: aminolevulinic acid, coproporphyrinogen, and protoporphyrin.
  • • Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase (ALAD), Coproporphyrinogen oxidase, and Ferrochelatase
  • • Due to this, lead poisoning can present with various symptoms, including anemia, punctate basophilia (bluish granules in RBCs), and elevated levels of these precursors. The most reliable diagnostic measure for lead poisoning is the blood lead level (> 70 μg/dl), which correlates best with adverse clinical symptoms and the toxicity profile of lead.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hair : While lead can be detected in hair, it does not correlate as well with the severity of poisoning or clinical symptoms as blood levels do.
  • • Option A. Hair
  • • Option C. Saliva : Saliva is not a standard sample for lead detection and does not provide reliable results.
  • • Option C. Saliva
  • • Option D. Urine : Though urine can show lead excretion, it is not as reliable as blood levels for correlating with toxicity and clinical manifestations.
  • • Option D. Urine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Blood lead levels are the most reliable and best indicator for detecting lead poisoning, correlating well with clinical symptoms and toxicity.
  • ➤ Laboratory diagnosis of Lead Poisoning –
  • ➤ Laboratory diagnosis of Lead Poisoning –
  • ➤ Porphyrinuria due to coproporphyrin III. Blood lead level > 70–100 μg/dl. Protoporphyrin > 35 μg/dl. Urine lead level > 0.15–0.3 mg/l.
  • ➤ Porphyrinuria due to coproporphyrin III.
  • ➤ Blood lead level > 70–100 μg/dl.
  • ➤ Protoporphyrin > 35 μg/dl.
  • ➤ Urine lead level > 0.15–0.3 mg/l.

questions.text: This child is suffering from: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Kwashiorkor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kwashiorkor is a Protein energy malnutrition caused by inadequate intake of protein with good calorie intake. C/F: abdominal and peripheral edema (swollen belly and legs) due to decreased serum albumin levels. Body fat stores are depleted, but weight for height is normal.
  • ➤ Kwashiorkor is a Protein energy malnutrition caused by inadequate intake of protein with good calorie intake.
  • ➤ C/F: abdominal and peripheral edema (swollen belly and legs) due to decreased serum albumin levels.
  • ➤ Body fat stores are depleted, but weight for height is normal.
  • ➤ Treatment – diet adequate in calories and protein.
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 532-533
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 532-533

questions.text: The true statement among the following is: (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: The dose of telmisartan should be reduced in severe renal failure but not in hepatic failure

options.label: B
options.text: The dose of irbesartan should be reduced in case of severe hepatic failure and but not in renal failure

options.label: C
options.text: The dose of olmisartan should be reduced in severe liver failure as well as in renal failure

options.label: D
options.text: Losartan acts as thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation

questions.correct_answer: D. Losartan acts as thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Losartan acts as thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ All ARBs should be avoided in moderate to severe renal disease due to risk of hyperkalemia. Except Olmesartan and Eprosartan, all other ARBs require dose adjustment in moderate to severe hepatic disease also. Losartan has additional antiplatelet action by acting as TXA2 receptor antagonist.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is not compliant with spectacles for her myopic astigmatism. What would be the appropriate management in her case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Spherical equivalent spectacles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Surgical interventions like LASIK and Femto LASIK are not recommended for individuals under 18 years of age.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has been diagnosed with tuberculosis. As part of his treatment plan, he is prescribed a combination of antitubercular drugs. While counseling him on the drug regimen, you explain the mechanisms of action of each drug. Which of the following combinations of statements accurately describe the mechanisms of some of the drugs used in treating tuberculosis? (INICET NOV 2022) Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis Pyrazinamide is an enzyme inducer Rifampicin is used only in the treatment of tuberculosis Bedaquiline inhibits ATP synthase
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis. Bedaquiline inhibits ATP synthase enzyme. Pyrazinamide inhibits trans-translation Rifampicin inhibit RNA polymerase
  • ➤ Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis.
  • ➤ Bedaquiline inhibits ATP synthase enzyme.
  • ➤ Pyrazinamide inhibits trans-translation
  • ➤ Rifampicin inhibit RNA polymerase

questions.text: Which marked structure causes lateral rotation, flexion, and abduction at the hip joint, along with flexion at the knee joint? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The muscle marked in the image are:
  • • The muscle marked in the image are:
  • • Option A. 1- Rectus femoris
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. 2- Vastus lateralis
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C . 3- Adductor longus
  • • Option C
  • • Option D . 4- Sartorius
  • • Option D
  • • Sartorius is involved in lateral rotation, flexion, and abduction at the hip joint, and flexion at the knee. The structure marked '4' is sartorius.
  • • The sartorius muscle is a long, thin muscle that runs down the front of the thigh. It is the body's longest muscle and is sometimes referred to as the tailor muscle because of the position that tailors often adopt while working. The sartorius muscle originates from the anterior superior iliac spine and the upper half of the notch below it, and runs obliquely across the thigh to insert into the superior aspect of the medial surface of the tibial shaft near the tibial tuberosity. It joins the aponeurosis of the gracilis and semitendinosus muscles to form the pes anserinus.
  • • The sartorius muscle is responsible for several actions, including flexion, abduction, and lateral rotation of the thigh, as well as flexion of the leg. Because of its location and actions, it is involved in many activities that require movement of the lower limb, such as walking, running, and climbing stairs.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Muscles of the anterior compartment of thigh (spinal segments in bold are the major segments innervating the muscle)
  • ➤ Muscles of the anterior compartment of thigh (spinal segments in bold are the major segments innervating the muscle)

questions.text: A 20-year-old female came with early satiety, massive splenomegaly, petechiae, and bleeding gums. Her hemoglobin was 8 gm/dl and TLC was 85,000/mm3. Which of the following is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) CML

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) should be strongly suspected in a patient presenting with massive splenomegaly , early satiety, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and a markedly elevated total leukocyte count with myeloid predominance .
  • ➤ massive splenomegaly
  • ➤ early satiety, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and a markedly elevated total leukocyte count with myeloid predominance
  • ➤ The presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, resulting from the reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, is the hallmark genetic abnormality in CML.

questions.text: In screening for diabetes in pregnancy, the dose of oral glucose load given is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 75g

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • For screening and diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), the oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is commonly used. The standard protocol involves a 75-gram oral glucose load.
  • • Protocol for 75-gram OGTT:
  • • International Guidelines: According to the International Association of Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Groups (IADPSG):
  • • International Guidelines: According to the International Association of Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Groups (IADPSG):
  • • The test is performed after an overnight fast. A fasting blood sample is taken. The woman is then given a 75-gram oral glucose load. Blood samples are taken at 1 hour and 2 hours after the glucose load. Diagnostic thresholds: Fasting glucose ≥ 92 mg/dL 1-hour glucose ≥ 180 mg/dL 2-hour glucose ≥ 153 mg/dL
  • • The test is performed after an overnight fast.
  • • A fasting blood sample is taken.
  • • The woman is then given a 75-gram oral glucose load.
  • • Blood samples are taken at 1 hour and 2 hours after the glucose load.
  • • Diagnostic thresholds: Fasting glucose ≥ 92 mg/dL 1-hour glucose ≥ 180 mg/dL 2-hour glucose ≥ 153 mg/dL
  • • Fasting glucose ≥ 92 mg/dL 1-hour glucose ≥ 180 mg/dL 2-hour glucose ≥ 153 mg/dL
  • • Fasting glucose ≥ 92 mg/dL
  • • 1-hour glucose ≥ 180 mg/dL
  • • 2-hour glucose ≥ 153 mg/dL
  • • A diagnosis of GDM is made if any one of these values is met or exceeded.
  • • DIPSI Criteria (India):
  • • DIPSI Criteria (India):
  • • This method can be used irrespective of the prandial state (whether the woman is fasting or not).
  • • A 75-gram oral glucose load is given. A blood sample is taken 2 hours later. A 2-hour plasma glucose value ≥ 140 mg/dL indicates GDM.
  • • A 75-gram oral glucose load is given.
  • • A blood sample is taken 2 hours later.
  • • A 2-hour plasma glucose value ≥ 140 mg/dL indicates GDM.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 50g : Used in the 50-gram glucose challenge test, which is a preliminary screening test, but not diagnostic.
  • • Option A. 50g
  • • Option C. 100g : Used in the 3-hour OGTT, which is less commonly used now compared to the 75-gram test.
  • • Option C. 100g
  • • Option D. 150g : Not used for GDM screening or diagnosis.
  • • Option D. 150g
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The current standard for screening and diagnosing gestational diabetes mellitus is the 75-gram oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT).

questions.text: Which tendon is palpable behind the medial malleolus on inversion of the foot? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Posterior tibialis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior tibialis tendon is palpable behind the medial malleolus during inversion of the foot and inserts on the navicular bone.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Trichomonas vaginalis? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: B
options.text: Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount

options.label: C
options.text: Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions

options.label: D
options.text: It is not a sexually transmitted infection

questions.correct_answer: B. Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with fever, loose stools, and blood in the stool. What is the enrichment medium used to isolate the organism from the stool sample? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Selenite F broth

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Selenite F broth is specifically used as an enrichment medium for isolating Shigella from stool samples in cases presenting with symptoms of dysentery, characterized by blood in the stools. This selective medium helps in the effective recovery of pathogens responsible for dysentery, aiding in accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.
  • ➤ Dysentery/Shigellosis is a type of food poisoning caused by infection with the Shigella species. It is spread through faeco-oral transmission. They are catalase-negative, non-lactose-fermenting, gram-negative rods, and are non-motile. It acts by inactivating the 60s ribosomal subunit thereby inhibiting protein synthesis. It causes acute onset of symptoms (fever, abdominal cramps) with dysentery and tenesmus. It also gives a positive Sereny test .
  • ➤ Dysentery/Shigellosis
  • ➤ acts by inactivating the 60s ribosomal subunit
  • ➤ a positive Sereny test

questions.text: Which of these is not a risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hepatitis B infection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hepatitis B infection is not a recognized risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma. Instead, focus on chronic inflammatory conditions, parasitic infections, and certain congenital disorders as key risk factors for this type of cancer.

questions.text: In the management of a thyroid storm, a critical and life-threatening condition due to an excess of thyroid hormone, a variety of medications are used to control the symptoms and the overactive thyroid. Which of the following drugs is NOT typically used in the treatment of thyroid storm? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Aspirin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspirin is not used in the treatment of thyroid storm because it can increase free thyroid hormone levels by displacing thyroid hormones from their binding proteins, potentially worsening the condition.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs undergoes Hoffman’s degradation? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cis-atracurium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cis-atracurium undergoes Hoffman’s degradation, a process independent of renal and hepatic function, making it suitable for use in patients with renal or hepatic impairment.

questions.text: A child presented with the following deformity and history of recurrent tooth abscess. On lab investigation, his serum calcium was normal, serum phosphorus was normal/reduced, serum PTH was normal, and ALP was increased. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A)  Hypophosphatemic rickets

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypophosphatemic rickets is characterized by normal PTH levels, normal/reduced phosphorus levels, and increased alkaline phosphatase (ALP). If PTH is normal in a case of suspected rickets, hypophosphatemic rickets should be strongly considered.
  • ➤ Hypophosphatemic rickets is characterized by normal PTH levels, normal/reduced phosphorus levels, and increased alkaline phosphatase (ALP).

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin shown in the image below. ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ig A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Secretory IgA is critical for mucosal immunity due to its unique structure and location. It acts as the first line of defence by preventing pathogens from adhering to and penetrating mucosal surfaces, thus playing a vital role in protecting the body from infections, especially at the mucosal barriers.

questions.text: Identify this condition. (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Condyloma acuminata

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows anogenital warts, which are characteristic of condyloma acuminata. These warts are caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV) and present as rough-surfaced papules and plaques in the anogenital region. The warts can vary in size and shape and are typically painless but can cause discomfort due to their location.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Herpes genitalis : This condition presents as grouped vesicles on an erythematous base. These vesicles can rupture to form polycyclic erosions.
  • • Option B. Herpes genitalis
  • • Option C. Condyloma lata : Associated with secondary syphilis, condyloma lata manifests as broad-based, moist, eroded, flat papules and plaques in the genital area.
  • • Option C. Condyloma lata
  • • Option D. Hemorrhoids : These are swollen and inflamed veins in the rectum and anus, presenting as bluish swollen lumps that can cause pain and bleeding. The image does not depict the typical appearance of hemorrhoids.
  • • Option D. Hemorrhoids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Condyloma acuminata presents as rough-surfaced papules and plaques in the anogenital area, characteristic of anogenital warts caused by HPV. Recognizing the appearance of these lesions is crucial for diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Which structure is supplied by the nerve causing this elevation? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Risorius

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Risorius is supplied by the facial nerve, resulting in the marked elevation. The image depicts the floor of the fourth ventricle, as well as the facial colliculus.
  • • The facial colliculus is a raised area on the floor of the fourth ventricle in the brainstem, and it is associated with the motor nucleus of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). The facial nerve is responsible for the motor innervation of the muscles of facial expression, including the risorius muscle, which is one of the muscles that can cause elevation of the corner of the mouth in smiling. Therefore, the structure that is supplied by the nerve causing this elevation would be the risorius muscle.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Lateral rectus: Is an extraocular muscle that arises from the lateral part of the common tendinous ring. It is innervated by the abducens nerve.
  • • Option A. Lateral rectus:
  • • Option B. Superior oblique: Is an extraocular muscle that arises from the body of the sphenoid. It is innervated by the trochlear nerve.
  • • Option B. Superior oblique:
  • • Option D. Levator palpebrae superioris: The levator palpebrae superioris muscle is supplied by the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III). This muscle is responsible for raising the upper eyelid (levator means "elevator"), allowing you to open your eyes.
  • • Option D. Levator palpebrae superioris:
  • • The oculomotor nerve also innervates several other muscles that control eye movement and pupil constriction, making it an important cranial nerve for eye function

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The risorius muscle, responsible for pulling the corner of the mouth laterally and aiding in expressions like smiling, is innervated by the facial nerve.

questions.text: Histological examination of a cervical lymph node biopsy is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of caseous necrosis and a ring of lymphocytes in the histological examination of cervical lymph nodes strongly suggests tuberculosis as the diagnosis.

questions.text: Match the following developmental milestones: ( INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Memorize the typical age ranges for key developmental milestones in infants, such as transferring objects, social smiling, pincer grasp, and walking.

questions.text: CSF otorrhea can occur in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Temporal Bone fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CSF otorrhea is a serious condition often linked with fractures of the temporal bone. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial to prevent complications and promote effective healing. Monitoring for signs of infection or persistent leakage is essential, as these may necessitate more aggressive interventions.

questions.text: All of the following are features of fragile X syndrome except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Micro-orchidism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following IV anesthetics acts on an NMDA receptor?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ketamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ketamine is unique among IV anesthetics for its action as an NMDA receptor antagonist, leading to its characteristic dissociative anesthesia.
